newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Peters, Bolger tight-lipped after NZ talks.
newsitem.headline: Peters, Bolger tight-lipped after NZ talks.

text.p: New Zealand's caretaker National Party government and the nationalist New Zealand First Party held their first talks on coalition-building on Monday, but neither side was prepared to comment in detail.
"We made good progress, but I hope I can make the same progress towards that door," New Zealand First leader Winston Peters said as he tried to squeeze past a scrum of reporters.
Caretaker Prime Minister Jim Bolger said the two sides would meet again at 2 p.m. (0100 GMT) on Wednesday, the same day NZ First is due to hold its first talks with the Labour Party.
New Zealand First, with 17 members of parliament, holds the balance of power after an inconclusive general election on October 12.

National and allies on the centre-right have 53 seats in the 120-member parliament. Labour has 37 and the left-wing Alliance won 13. The conservative National Party has governed since 1990. National and Labour both aim to form a government with support from New Zealand First, which has said it will negotiate with both simultaneously in a process that could take many weeks.
Bolger and Peters made no further comment on the initial talks, which lasted about an hour and 40 minutes.
